Citation: Verbert, K., Duval, E., Klerkx, J., Govaerts, S., & Santos, J. L. (2013). Learning analytics dashboard applications. American Behavioral Scientist, 57(10), 1500-1509.

Citation: Lockyer, L., Heathcote, E., & Dawson, S. (2013). Informing pedagogical action: Aligning learning analytics with learning design. American Behavioral Scientist, 57(10), 1439-1459.
Description: This paper proposes a connection between learning design and learning analytics.  The paper then demonstrates this connection with the SNAPP visualization tool, a graph-based viz for interactions in discussion forum
CommentsCVG: The paper presents a summary of visualizations and learning analytics tools in Table I, and discusses Social network diagrams in more detail to inform their design and interpretation of the visualizations
CommentsCET:
The paper advocates for a strong connection between learning analytics and learning design "any user interaction behavior must be analyzed in the specific education context such as the learning design 
and course modality. An understanding of the learning design context is imperative for establishing accurate predictive models alongside pedagogical recommendations. "
CommentsSoV: Simple graph visualization that allows limited interaction, and it only shows one level of the data.

Citation: Nagy, R. P. (2016). Tracking and Visualising Student Effort: Evolution of a Practical Analytics Tool for Staff and Student Engagement. Journal of Learning Analytics, 3(2), 164-192.
Description: Provides a visualization tool of students' effortm for teachers to assess students and to provide formative feedback
CommentsCVG: No background on visualization strategies
CommentsCET: Provides a review of background literature on students' effort and its effect for motivation and learning. The study discusses the findings under the existing literature, and somewhat informs the design by establishing the constructs to assess
